This is all things considered from NPR News I'm Ari Shapiro and I noticed a change in the weeks since Christine Blasey Ford accused Supreme Court nominee Brett
Kavanaugh sexual assault President Trump's response has been relatively restraint that changed completely last night and the president from mocked Ford at a rally in Mississippi
How did you get home I don't remember how did you get there I don't remember where is the place and I don't remember how many years and they in
The White House briefing room for a secretary Sarah Sanders defended the president's comments NPR's Danielle Kurtzleben has been following the president's response to all of this controversy and she joins us now Hey Daniel hello
So as we noted the president's tone it shifted dramatically last night and I just want to start out by talking about how his comments last night compared to how he's been talking about Ford up until last night
Sure so late last week after Christine Blasey Ford and Brett Kavanaugh testified before the Senate Judiciary committee Trump had taken a much softer tone towards Christine Blasey
Ford Motor testimony is very compelling and she looks like a very fine woman [noise] now he
Seems to be sort of healing to the line that congressional Republicans seem to be healing to which was something to the effect of Christine Blasey Ford seems credible you know maybe the ...
Then last night he got up in front of the crowd and he he was mimicking her and the fact that you know she can't remember every single thing that happened that night so he was really the verging from that line and he was playing it to last and cheers from that audience yeah you can hear the tape and so that has people really upset today
Some how the response has been in the Senate because to get Kavanaugh through Senate Republicans are focusing on two key senators Lisa Murkowski of Alaska and Susan Collins of Maine how either of those two women responded to Trump's comments from last night
Right well they're not happy or Lisa Murkowski has said her words were that it's inappropriate and unacceptable and that Trump's comments could sway her vote now Susan Collins likewise she told CNN that it was quote just plain wrong what Trump said and she wouldn't say if it would affect her vote
You know one thing that has been swirling in the middle of all of this is the fact that Trump has talked about how he actually emphasizes with Kavanaugh because he himself has been accused of sexual assault of sexual misconduct absolutely
He has more than a dozen accusations of misconduct against him and like Brett Kavanaugh Trump is denying all of the allegations against him but that's not the only echo here I mean let's look at how Trump has responded to those allegations likewise
And one of those allegations against Trump Jessica leads that woman who said he had groped her on an airplane decades ago he also mocked her after that allegation came out the quote that he said was she wouldn't be my first choice she likewise said that to a crowd the crowd likewise lasted shared
And you know he was really he really seemed to be saying she's an attractive and that wouldn't have happened therefore
Soap the important thing that we're trying to get out here though is that we have a pet or not only of how Trump reacts to sexual misconduct allegations
But how his supporters react
And his supporters by and large seemed to have stuck with him through the allegations against him even if they find those allegations distasteful

Chang and I'm Ari Shapiro many people in the U.S auto industry are breathing a sigh of relief this week the new trade deal between the U.S Mexico and Canada and months of uncertainty if it's approved by Congress it will spare carmakers from some of the terrorists that they had feared
And we'll send a senior vice president of the motor and equipment Manufacturers Association which represents more than a thousand companies that make all this
For listeners what you remember companies making and where you are in the auto making supply chain
So our members make the vast majority of the content for new vehicles and we also manufacture parts and components for maintenance and repair
And how much was on the line for you in this trade agreement ... holding their breath to see what the details would be
Well our industry has actually done quite well under NAFTA we've actually been able to grow our supply chain in North America we've been able to grow manufacturing jobs in the United states but it counts and all three countries being part of the agreement
So we are very pleased relieved that all three parties were able to come to an agreement this weekend we're cautiously optimistic that the terms in agreement will work for the industry and for the American public
When you look at the details of the agreement can you tell how it compares to NAFTA for you
Well there's going to be an increase in the amount of North American content that will be required
For parts to travel through the three countries are going to have to call it the U.S Mexico Canada agreement but traveled through North America without having to pay tariffs there's going to be a requirement for more North American steel and aluminum
Us so all of that would impact our members and in addition there's going to be some new administrative costs that are going to be required
One of the concerns we have though are there some new tariffs out there right now on steel and aluminum and we'd like to see Canada and the United states address that before the final ISIS agreement and the end of November
So on the one hand there won't be terrorists for material crossing Canada U.S Mexico border is on the other hand the steel and aluminum tariffs that were of concern to your industry have not gone away
No they haven't I think one of the things we have the mind as they have been a particular burden to smaller manufacturers many of these smaller manufacturers are only in the U.S
And some of our members have seen the cost of their steel purchases rise almost fifty percent so this is her significant increase
It's particularly of concern between Canada and the United states we'd like to see those two countries roll up the sleaze you the same energy they use to conclude that this new NAFTA and be able to come to some kind of agreement on steel and aluminum tariffs
I Know that there's a lot of relief from the auto industry now the uncertainty is gone but how does this compare to the old rules under NAFTA isn't an improvement
Little pool through was an increase in the U.S content and for some of our suppliers and some component manufacturers this is going to be a challenge there's no doubt about that
I Do think that we're going to see more steel moral woman that from North America in our vehicles
The biggest concern our members are going to have the administrators cost and we're gonna have to work really hard with all three parties can minimize those costs because the consumers are going to get any value out of bed and that's going to be our next a real challenge for as we move forward that Greenland
And Wilson is senior vice president of the motor and equipment Manufacturers Association thanks for speaking with us today thank you pleasure

Communities across the country are grappling with a new kind of chemical pollution in drinking water it called peace at a group of thousands of chemical use for decades and products like ... pans
To science and regulation around this still aren't settled leaving some people in limbo New Hampshire Public Radio's Annie Ropeik has the story
Jillian lanes family built a house in a tree lined cul de sac in the New Hampshire town of ... on a recent morning as she wrangled her three young daughters of the door she pointed out a picture window for the woods in the backyard
And
What it is a federal Superfund site called Coakley landfill lane didn't even know it was there until two years ago when she heard of a nightmarish discovery nearby a cancer cluster of young kids all with the same rare deadly diagnoses
Lane was desperate to know or for girls were risk so she started reading
Underneath one of the articles was just a comment from a Public Citizen that set a Coakley question mark when I was like totally attackers ... started Googling it
She found a former town ... turned toxic waste cleanup area just through the woods and ... [noise] Bob some of the city attorney is nearby port Smith he says the landfill no huge grassy hill used to be an empty Corey
And that was actually kind of stayed in the eye back in the Nineteen seventies when people looking to get rid of municipal waste trash they would find a hole in somewhere in Philadelphia [noise] probably seemed like a good idea
Heavy metals and manmade toxins were seeping from a landfill
With a cap to keep Iran from washing out more Thompson's for years this put the public fears to rest then made news of the cancer cluster in twenty sixteen workers made an alarming discovery high levels of pee fast chemicals and surface waters around the landfill
Since then traces of these industrial toxins have also turned up in nearby wells
Officials are still working to pinpoint where the chemicals come from and they may never be sure what caused the cancer cluster but peace has chemicals have been linked to a wide range of health effects including cancer so neighbors like Jillian lane are still terrified
Right and so were drinking the water and wear bathing in it were brush our teeth in it and we have no idea that we're living with a potential problem
Lanes family spent thousands of dollars on high tech water filters and she devoted countless hours to public meetings and petitions for more clean up an aid
The environmental protection agency says the ... in nearby wells is not a threat based on state and federal standards but that doesn't quite line up with a June ... report from the Centers for Disease Control it says pee fast may threatened human health at levels ten times lower than what the EPA in states like New Hampshire advise
At a recent federal meeting on the fast and New Hampshire atop CDC official ... tried to clarify
This is not a larger if we're not saying exposures estimated minimal risk levels to be associated
He says the CDC focuses on public health not regulations so it's research could play into new state and federal standards and the future And Julian lands well the ... level is lower even than what the CDC says may be risky but she's still feels the government is failing her community
The public shouldn't have to be driving this process you know none of that contributed to building trust with the public
Pee fast chemicals have not sick and her children but they have left a different mark late this summer the family decided to move away lane says she'll keep up her activism she just doesn't want to live near Coakley landfill anymore for NPR News I'm Annie Ropeik in Greenland New Hampshire [noise]

As central database did the inspector general find that central database
The inspector general found no evidence that there was such a central database the two agencies actually had computer systems that could not communicate with each other and the inspector general found that when distraught parents tried to track down their children the government sometimes gave them inconsistent or just wrong information in some cases parents couldn't communicate with their kids at all
And it has reconnected more than two thousand children with their parents but the inspector general's report says that this lack of communication made that reunification process slower
And the process was especially hard for children who are still young that they couldn't speak immigration authorities according to this report made no effort to identify those young children it anyway no wristbands and no photographs of them were taken so it was only through communication with the parents that that authorities were able to find these children and reunite them
Still have federal officials responded to the inspector general's report in any way
Well as the administration often does it is blaming quote immigration laws that are broken and poorly written unquote
Da chess does say that it deserves some credit for working quote exhaustively to reunite these families although again they were ordered to do so by a judge but the H. S. also acknowledge that the government's computer systems still do not communicate across these agencies
Are there any children still haven't been reunited with their parents
